user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_single_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_single_response (void *cls,
                        struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                        const char *url,
                        const char *method,
                        const char *version,
                        const char *upload_data,
                        size_t *upload_data_size,
                        void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

  return MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, resp_single);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function answer_single_response:
#define MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET "GET"
...
#define MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD "HEAD"
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */
explanation: The only use of <string.h> functions in this function is strcmp; that call may access memory via the 'method' pointer beyond its bounds if 'method' is NULL or not a properly terminated string (or otherwise points to a smaller buffer). The macros MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET and MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD are string literals (null-terminated) so passing them to strcmp is safe. Other fragments do not call any string.h functions and therefore cannot violate Rule 21.17: the (void) casts merely suppress unused-parameter warnings; assigning &marker to *req_cls is a pointer store that does not use string functions; the early return and the call to MHD_queue_response do not involve <string.h> operations. Consequently only the strcmp-based conditional needs further investigation.
